advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> <font color="#666666">The 8813 was built with you, the professional, in mind...<br><br> Using the 8813, one person can process what would normally require many secretaries, several bookkeepers and a great deal of time...<br><br> The 8813 slashes the professional's overhead. It's a powerful time and money-saving ally. Prices for complete system including printer start at less than $8,000.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 6</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad is unique in that it features professional actors and IMSAI employees. <p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRIDGE COMPUTER VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1982, the <b>Bridge Computer Company</b> (Newton, MASS) sold a Z80 software developper system with the InterSystems mainframe, CP/M 2.2 operating system and various optional programming languages.The configuration was:<br><br> - 6 Mhz. Z80-B CPU with memory management<br> - 256 KB RAM expandable to 1 MB<br> - Two 8" or 5.25" F.D. drives, single or double sided<br> - Optional 5" or 8" hard disk, up to 40 MB<br> - Televideo serial video terminal. <br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Does this sound too good to be true? Just fill your tank with the BRIDGE 3C formula for SPEED and shift into 'overdrive' with your bridge 3C Compiler System. Leave the other behind, let us provide you with the fuel for higher productivity...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Two generations amazed...</b> <br><br> Perhaps a bit too much though... but the scene is beautiful and we can only admire the originality of the Philips' communication campaign which, for once, is not exclusively focused on the young Basic apprentices.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual floppy drive version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www1.cts.ne.jp/~sato/hp/">Sato's Homepage</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Why paying more ?"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> F.D. UNIT ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>BBC floppy disc unit was delivered with a 8271 FD controller chip and a Filing System software in ROM to be fitted into the BBC system.<br> Two versions of F.D. units were available:<br> - A single drive unit, single side, single density, 100 KB space.<br> - A dual drive version, double side, double density, 800 KB space. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRAPPING MAN!</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> A compact problem-solving add for engineers, statisticians, scientists and financial and business analysts. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.peekandpoke.org" target="_blank">www.peekandpoke.org</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>

computer.description:
This pong is exactly the same system as the Binatone TV Master MK IV, but marketed under a different name.
See this entry for more info...
